The adafdr API reference¶

adafdr_explore¶

adafdr.method.adafdr_explore(p_input, x_input, alpha=0.1, n_full=None, vis_dim=None, covariate_type=None, cate_name={}, output_folder=None, title_list=None, h=None, figsize=[5, 3])[source]¶

Covariate exploration.

For each covariate, provide a visualization of its relationship with the p-value, as well as an estimate of the alternative and the null proportion.

Parameters:
  • p_input (NumPy array, shape (n,)) – p-value.
  • x_input (NumPy array, shape (n,d)) – Covaraites. The ordinal/categorical features should be coded by integers starting from 0.
  • alpha (float) – Nominal FDR level.
  • n_full (int) – Total number of hypotheses before p-vlaue filtering.
  • covariate_type (0/1 list or boolean NumPy array, shape (d,)) – Type of each covariate. False/0 means numerical/ordinal while True/1 means categorical. This is optional. If not given, covaraites with less than 75 distinct values are treated as categorical. Otherwise is treated as numerical/ordinal.
  • vis_dim (list or int NumPy array) – The dimensions to visualize
  • cate_name (dictionary of dictionaries) – the category names for each categorical covariate. The value is None when the category names are not available. An example is as follows: cate_name = {1: {0: ‘name0’, 1: ‘name1’}}. Here, covariate 0 has no names. Dimension 1 is categorical and has two values 0,1, whose corresponding names are name0, name1
  • output_folder (str) – Output directory.
  • title_list (list of strings) – Titles for each figure.
  • h (boolean NumPy array, shape (n,)) – Ground truth. 1 mean alternative while 0 means null (None if not available).

adafdr_test¶

adafdr.method.adafdr_test(p_input, x_input, K=5, alpha=0.1, n_full=None, n_itr=1500, qt_norm=True, covariate_type=None, h=None, verbose=False, output_folder=None, random_state=0, single_core=True, fast_mode=True)[source]¶

Covariate-adaptive multiple testing.

Main function for covariate-adaptive multiple testing.

Parameters:
  • p_input (NumPy array, shape (n,)) – p-value.
  • x_input (NumPy array, shape (n,d)) – Covaraites. The ordinal/categorical features should be coded by integers starting from 0.
  • K (int) – Number of mixture components.
  • alpha (float) – Nominal FDR level.
  • n_full (int) – Total number of hypotheses before p-vlaue filtering.
  • n_itr (int) – number of iterations for optimization.
  • qt_norm (boolean) – If perform quantile normalization.
  • covariate_type (0/1 list or boolean NumPy array, shape (d,)) – Type of each covariate. False/0 means numerical/ordinal while True/1 means categorical. This is optional. If not given, covaraites with less than 75 distinct values are treated as categorical. Otherwise is treated as numerical/ordinal.
  • h (boolean NumPy array, shape (n,)) – Ground truth. 1 means alternative while 0 means null (None if not available).
  • verbose (boolean) – Indicate if output the computation details.
  • output_folder (str) – Output directory.
  • random_state (int) – Random seed.
  • single_core (boolean) – True if use single core and False for two cores in parallel.
  • fast_mode (boolean) – If True, run adafdr_fast without optimization (recommended).
Returns:

res, the result dictionary. res[‘decision’]: a (n,) boolean vector, decision for each hypothesis with value 1 meaning rejection. res[‘threshold’]: a (n,) float vector, threshold for each hypothesis.
Return type:

dictionary
